title: If the 'self' does not exist, who or what are you? - Quora

response.answer_text: Socratic questions have no final answer. What is justice? What is The Good? But a more important question that has to be answered prior to answering “What are you?” is “What is consciousness?” The Cogito or “I think therefore I am” runs into serious trouble when faced with modern brain science. Brain makes decisions before you even know it If decisions have been made before you are “conscious” (whatever that means) of them, what role does the “I” in “Cogito Ergo Sum” come from? Maybe there are multiple perspectives that fight it out in a kind of democratic process before “consciousness” is notified of the results. Maybe “I” should actually be “We.” However many people are poking fun at buddhism when the ask the question in the OP. “No-self” has special meaning in Eastern philosophy. It is related to Wu wei or “non action.” I think both concepts refer to the kind of effortless being that comes from a flow state, but in this case it isn’t just any flow state. It is the flow state associated with someone who has practiced mindfulness long enough for it to become internalized. Think of it this way. Mindfulness practice involves examining thoughts, feelings and perceptions as they occur and doing one’s best to be non judgemental about them. There comes a time where you can notice a thought and not feel attached to it. There will come a moment where you will think to yourself “Who originated that thought?” Then you will look for the origin of that thought, but no matter how hard you look you will not find it. Is that because there is nothing there? Is it because you are unable to recognize something even though it is there? Is it because what you can recognize is a part of a structure that you can’t comprehend all at once? Is the mind like a wave/process that reveals its structure over time and what we are doing is like trying to see a movie in a still photo? Why do we believe that that a brain is capable of understanding itself? I don’t know. Neither do you. Most likely no one will ever know. Maybe no one CAN ever know. So in this way the self both exists and does not exist. Non duality. Who needs drugs when we have puzzles like this? Antigonish by William Hughes Mearns "Yesterday, upon the stair, I met a man who wasn't there! He wasn't there again today, Oh how I wish he'd go away!" When I came home last night at three, The man was waiting there for me But when I looked around the hall, I couldn't see him there at all! Go away, go away, don't you come back any more! Go away, go away, and please don't slam the door... Last night I saw upon the stair, A little man who wasn't there, He wasn't there again today Oh, how I wish he'd go away...

Answer me this: Do you exist? Don’t think about it, just notice are you, or are you not? Many non-duality teachings make it very confusing by saying things like “there is no you” or “there is no self”. If they do not explain exactly what they mean, this can end up being very confusing because you most certainly have a sense of being, of existing. You are, and that’s undeniable. All that they are saying is that the story you superimpose upon this obvious self-evident beingness is the “self” that doesn’t exist. The you that is, without a story, before the story, after the story - that is the Real. However, you may want to understand that non-duality makes use of this knowledge in a particular way, and it doesn’t actually have to be used in this way. I will explain: Non-duality focuses on real versus unreal, lasting versus ephemeral, liberation from that which is imaginary. The belief behind this is that bliss or lasting peace and happiness are to be found only through awakening to that which is eternal and ever-present, and no longer believing in the “small self”. That is one way to look at it. Another way to look at it is that you are being one person or another in any given moment. You’re always telling a story, and that is the story you are living. You are not limited by the person you are being or the story you are telling and truly you are beyond it, that I AM that is ever-present. However, as long as you are expressing yourself in physical terms, you will be this person or other, tell one story or other. There is no way to avoid that. Your choices and actions indicate who you are being. You can actually decide who you prefer to be, consciously, and your choices and actions will flow out of that decision. This is conscious creation, as opposed to automatic reaction. Since the person is an illusion, you can actually consciously create it, for understand — you will create one illusion or another. You are dreaming, and the realization that you are dreaming doesn’t make you cease to experience it. You don’t have to keep the dream at bay, as though it something to defend against lest it pulls you into samsara and suffering — you can consciously own your dream, as the dreamer of it. In this way you will find that you are able to do “miracles”. But it is not for your ego, it is simply because you understand that your dream is YOUR dream, and that absolutely everything that you experience you are doing to yourself. There is no objective world; there is nothing outside of you. It’s all you. And you’re always deciding to be one way or another. To be or not to be is NOT the question, for you are and that’s non-negotiable. But HOW to be — this you are deciding in each and every moment, and “the person” that you may have thought you are was never a solid or fixed thing, but an ever-changing expression of the eternal you. Only you were never conscious of this. That what you call “the person” is constantly changing — and that you can take conscious control over this, for you are deciding who you are anyway. You’ve been simply doing it unconsciously, and I am saying that you can do it consciously. The knowledge that all of this is an illusion — all of physical reality and the person — can be USED in more ways than one. In the non-dual community there is no emphasis on that you are CREATIVE being, only on that you are pure being. That is because the common definition of liberation within this view is the awakening FROM the dream. Surely there is a great relief in knowing and seeing that you are not at the effect of anything that happens in this dream. To your being nothing ever happens. This is the part of the awakening that I call: “nothing happens TO you”, and yet I add another part to it: “everything happens FROM you”. And this is the part that I am speaking about. That while you truly are not affected by anything in this dream, you are 100% responsible for all that you see, for you see only what you project. The world arises and subsides in you. It’s not “out there”. You are only experiencing yourself. Many times people come to me after feeling that they’ve understood that first part of liberation - “nothing happens TO Me”, and yet their life is in shambles… it’s a mess… and they still have to live it. That’s where in our sessions we begin to practice that “everything happens from You”, and they begin to direct their dream consciously, and live in the power of who they really are. Now, the objection of non-dualists is that you shouldn’t be focused on changing the dream, only waking up from it. We are not, in my case, changing the dream in order to stay asleep. We must understand that many times the awakening will not abide unless certain beliefs and attitudes are worked on. The change in the dream is a side-effect of shifting those beliefs. As you purify you inner-world, so does the outer become a clear reflection of your nature. The dream is to be USED rather than denied. It lets you know how clear and free of judgment and separation you are within your consciousness. Like a mirror, it does not lie. It can teach you what you hold within you that is not in line with your actual nature. And as you shift it, so the reflection must change. Your alignment is important. If your allegiance is to your mask rather than your true nature, this will show up in your actions and choices in the dream. You have to be conscious about the place from which you are acting. The improvement in the dream is a byproduct of alignment with your nature. It does not cause you to sleep, for you are not invested in outcomes in the dream, yet that does not mean you deny responsibility for what appears to happen to you in the dream. In my view, there are not two yous. This is confusing. There is just you. The ever-present you. While your experience may shift, you are always here to experience whatever form it is taking. That which we call “the small self” doesn’t exist. There is just one of you. The one that IS, that exists. And this one expresses itself either consciously or unconsciously. But you cannot withhold expressing your Self.

The SELF does exist. It’s just not divided into many. It is ONE self or Pure Awareness looking through the eyes of all the forms it takes from human, to animal, to plant, to alien. Responding to this question requires us to first define what we mean by the ‘self’. If by ‘self’ we mean that which we refer to as the “I” living in an individual body-mind with all of its particular physical, chemical and genetic features with distinguishing traits and tendencies of thought and feeling and perception, then that ‘self’ does not exist. That self is illusory. If by SELF we mean that which we refer to as the “I” which KNOWS or is AWARE of our experience, then that Self does exist. It just doesn’t exist APART from any ‘other’ self. To be more precise, the SELF does not exist per say, because existence means to ‘stand out’ from. If the SELF is ALL THERE IS (infinite and omnipresent), then it cannot ‘stand out’. It must be WHOLE, undivided - not apart from Reality, but Reality itself. ISNESS or BEING itself. I Am - WE ARE or WE SHARE - our very BEING.

“The self” is a construct, a designation. “You”, are a collection of aggregates of perception that interact with an external reality. “Your body” is born from a collection of your mother’s ovum and father’s sperm. Is it actually a body, or is it your mothers egg and father’s sperm? Every scar and marking on your body, it’s weight, the health of your teeth ect are dependent on external factors, and not actually the body itself. The self does not exist, not because you are nothing, and not because nothing exists. The self does not exist, because nothing can exist on it’s own. It is all a creation dependent on other factors. Buddhist note that the fundamentally most important factor is mind. Good and bad, hope and lose, these ideas are purely memory, like a dream. When we tap into this, fully, we control the dream and overcome all ill-being. Reality as a whole, self and external factors, are actually a creation of mind. We can see how our attitudes, decisions and actions shape the world that we live in, and so, they are our reality. In every moment, you are shaping your own reality. “You” are not nothing, but “you” are actually infinite. This is the true meaning of emptiness. Tashi.

I am a collection of chemical reactions housed in my brain. Everything I am and everything I ever will be is just that, chemical reactions. I understand that I am just a collection of cells that happen to make up a human. The only reason I have sentience is because my brain happens to allow thoughts and rational thinking. Things that have been developed since the beginning of life on earth. I understand that, as hard as it is to admit, once I die all my biological functions (including thinking) will cease. So, if self doesn’t exist, which I don’t believe it does in a literal sense… I am just a collection of some organic material that happens to be speaking.. Actually I’m like 70% water. I guess you could say I’m water.

The questions relates back to the context in which the term “self” is used. If we are talking about the concept of “self” as in the “True Self”. Then it does exist but its probably deeply buried under a mountain of perceptions called “my self”, “your self” and “them selves”. “My self”: What I think I am is not what I really am. Ask yourself this: How many times have we overvalued/undervalued ourselves?How many times have we wanted to do something, but found that it was not what we really wanted? Or did not do something but it was what we really needed?How many times have we been influenced by others perceptions with/against our own judgement?“Your self”: What others think you are is not what you really are. But it may affect the way you perceive yourself. Our parents/friends/colleagues perceptions of us are but a tiny fragment of what we really are. Some may come close, but no one really scratches the surface of our “secrets”.e.g. My parents/friends may say that I am smart. But am I really smart? They may really mean it, but is this true? Do I now go into society with the feeling that I am a genius?How many times have you heard a term similar to “That’s just like you!” or “That’s what you would do!”? But your mind was going “What the hell? That’s not me at all!” and then upon reflection, maybe that is me after all? Or is it?How many times have we thought that we knew someone well, only to have the situation of “I don’t know you anymore!” comes around? Well guess what? They probably do not know you much either.“Them selves”: What general social groups tend to label me as is not what I really am. Almost automatic assumptions of certain characteristics and behavior because we are part of a certain social/racial/religious group, whether it is true or not, may affect how we perceive ourselves. It might be something as harmless as:Person A is working as IT, they must know how to repair a computer. (Obviously not true for all IT people, but there are some who fit the bill)Asian food is mostly served with rice, or Italian food is mostly pizzas and pasta. (Obviously not true, but we can have our opinions, no harm done, I guess.)The list goes on……………………Then there are those mis-conceptions that could ruin some ones/society/countries day:Country X is a bad country because of “political agenda exhibit 1”. Country Y is a bad country because of “political agenda exhibit 2”.Race A are “insert racist slur 1”, Race B are “insert racist slur 2” and Race C are “insert racist slur 3” (I wonder what people are saying about my race…)My Country, Religion, Culture and Race are the best things in the world!!! (or is it?)The list goes on……………………Apart from all these perceptions of ourselves, internal and external. Does that mean the True Self does not exit? Actually it does. The problem is with identifying it with all the shaded glasses we are wearing. Whether those glasses are applied internally or externally. We may never get to know who or what we really are. Perhaps finding out may lead to an unfathomable depths of truths and wisdom, or it could lead to nothing at all. Is not life about looking for answers?

That is really the ultimate question. Who or what am I? We know we have a physical part. We can experience through our bodies. What we tend to think of as ourselves is a collection of memories. Mess with the memories and you change the personality. Would there or could there be something else? Something that as long as you can recall has been present. Something that every once in a while you get a tiny glimpse of but can never figure out what it is. When you remove all of the beliefs, philosophies, fears, interests and memories there is something behind it. Find that and you will know the answer to the question.

Nothingness. It too doesn't encompass the entirety of who You are. You cannot name, think, speak about something that is not subjecting the subject to a Form. Name is Form. Qualifying is Form. Saying something as something is Form. Saying something as “Self” is also Form. Saying something as “Non-Self” is Form. So how does one describe the Infinite, where saying that it is, thinking as it is, knowing as it is, and isn't are all Limitations of Form. Nearest to say with point in limitation is “I am that I AM.”

Good question, It is very simple really: There is only One Self. Oneself is reality. Oneself is existence. All plurality is in truth Oneself. Oneself perceives itself as diversified not to be alone, for companionship. As such all religions are correct for they all lead to the same truth. Christianity explains this need for companionship as Love. Islam explains this as Companionship or Friendship. Judaism explains this ‘all is G-d’ or ‘Ahava’. Hinduism explains this as ‘Om Tat Sat’ or ‘Aham Brahmasmi’ or Truth is One (Rigveda). And so on. And so on. In conclusion: Truth is Oneself desiring companionship. Wald Wassermann

Non-dual cosnciousness/sentience/soul. Talking about it can point to it. But you have to experience it to understand what I mean. Non-dual =infinite. Our brains are dualistic and thus infinity can not operate on the level of thought. The closest we can get is experiencing it in meditation. In the same way an eye can’t see itself, we can’t see it. It’s the essence that allows for seeing.
The “self” isn’t what you think it is. If you fully understand this, you are said to be enlightened. Note also nothing changes about who or what you are once you are enlightened. Think about that.

“No self” is one of the absurdities and delusions of Buddhism teachings. Do you ever encounter a person who has no sense of self? A sense of self (self-awareness) is a normal human development. Read any standard psychology textbook. Now Buddhism teaching, through meditation and mindfulness, wants you to lose your sense of your self, turning you back into an infant (or a pig)! It’s a madness, but Buddhism teaching calls this Enlightenment. Shockingly, even many scientists in the west lose their minds and become deluded into believing and promoting this “No Self” delusion.

The brain creates the “self“ in order to deal with reality. Basically, it is an illusion but a functional one, or two, or three, or more, however many are needed for the brain to navigate in this world. The brain is me. Duality? Spirit, soul? There is no ghost in the machine.
The one who is asking this question. What will you call yourself “self or no-self”, “exist or non-exist”.
But it does. Or at least it certainly seems as though it does. Cogito ergo sum. I think therefore I am.
You have posed a question of semantics. Unfortunately, that is an area that is rife with invention (opinion) and devoid of consensus (agreement). I don't weigh in on those questions. C.H.
